title: Be eco-friendly this Diwali!
text:
Rangoli

We love decorating our homes during festivals. One such way is through the art of rangoli. Apart from being aesthetically pleasing, it is also believed to bring good luck and is a way of welcoming the goddess Laxmi. What we fail to realise is that these bright colours are loaded with chemicals such as mercury, lead and bromides and are really harmful. Doctors even warn that continuous exposure to these colours has hazardous effects. They are also harmful to the environment and should be banned altogether. Instead of buying colours laced with chemicals, opt for eco-friendly colours or simply head straight to your kitchen and make your own rangoli colours with kitchen ingredients. Spices such as turmeric and mild chilli powder both make excellent rangoli colours. Other spices such as star anise or cinnamon sticks can be used to make beautiful patterns. It doesn’t just stop there. You can also design an art form out of coloured sand, shells, leaves and flowers or even rice. There’s really no stopping when it comes to sourcing material for your next art piece.
description: Let’s do our bit to ensure that our future remains well lit! Here are some ideas on how you can have an eco-friendly festival of lights
